Interviewer
Hello and welcome everyone. I'm Corey Hofstein and this is Flirting with Models, the podcast that pulls back the curtain to discover the human factor behind the quantitative strategy. Corey Hofstein is the co-founder and chief investment officer of Newfound Research. Due to industry regulations, he will not discuss any of Newfound Research's funds on this podcast. All opinions expressed by podcast participants are solely their own opinion and do not reflect the opinion of Newfound Research. This podcast is for informational purposes only and should not be relied upon as a basis for investment decisions. Clients of Newfound Research may maintain positions and securities discussed in this podcast. For more information, visit thinknewfound.com. In this episode, I am joined by J.D. Gardner, founder and managing member at Aptis Capital. In his time in the industry, J.D. has served in the role of associate financial advisor, analyst at a deep value equity fund, and analyst at a deep value equity fund. A short-term, systematic managed futures fund. These varying experiences have mixed to culminate into J.D.'s ultimate philosophy. It's all about the investor's return, not the investment return. I like to say no pain, no premium, as a pithy shorthand for the notion that long-term outperformance requires short-term pain along the way. For J.D. and the team at Aptis, their funds are first and foremost, governed by the question of achievability. For them, the contest is not in the theoretical purity of your factor exposure, but rather whether the investor can stick around long enough to actually harvest it. A theoretically sub-optimal solution can be best if it helps the investor bridge the behavior gap. In light of this philosophy, the team at Aptis has launched two strategies. We discussed their fortified value index, one of the more unique spins on value investing that I've come across. Not only does the strategy aim to employ a measure of value that leads to greater investor returns, but it also rolls out-of-the-money put options in effort to protect the portfolio against sudden short-term declines in value that may otherwise invite client misbehavior. Classic Graham and Dodd value investing, this is not. But for some, J.D. argues, a much more achievable alternative. J.D., thank you for joining me today.

大家好，欢迎收听。我是Corey Hofstein，这里是《Flirting with Models》播客，我们揭开幕后，探索量化策略背后的人为因素。Corey Hofstein是Newfound Research的联合创始人和首席投资官。由于行业规定，他不会在播客中讨论Newfound Research的任何基金。播客参与者的所有观点仅代表他们个人，并不代表Newfound Research的立场。本播客仅用于信息目的，不应作为投资决策的依据。Newfound Research的客户可能持有本播客中讨论的仓位和证券。更多信息，请访问thinknewfound.com。在本期节目中，我邀请到了Aptis Capital的创始人兼管理成员J.D. Gardner。在行业中，J.D.曾担任过金融顾问助理、深度价值股票基金分析师以及短期系统化管理期货基金分析师。这些不同的经历最终融合成了J.D.的核心理念：一切都是为了投资者的回报，而非投资回报。我喜欢用“没有痛苦，就没有溢价”来简洁地表达这一观点，即长期的超额表现需要短期的痛苦作为代价。对于J.D.和Aptis团队来说，他们的基金首先受到可行性问题的制约。对他们而言，关键不在于你的因子暴露在理论上有多纯粹，而在于投资者是否能坚持足够长的时间来真正收获这些回报。一个理论上次优的解决方案，如果能够帮助投资者跨越行为差距，那么它就是最佳的。基于这一理念，Aptis团队推出了两种策略。我们讨论了他们的强化价值指数，这是我见过的对价值投资更为独特的诠释之一。该策略不仅旨在采用一种能带来更高投资者回报的价值衡量方法，还通过卖出虚值看跌期权来保护投资组合免受可能引发客户错误行为的短期价值突然下跌的影响。这不是经典的格雷厄姆和多德式的价值投资，但对某些人来说，J.D.认为，这是一个更为可行的替代方案。J.D.，感谢你今天的参与。

Customer

Interviewer
I've often found the behavioral finance lessons really hit home when you see them firsthand. And a lot of portfolio managers that I've spoken to that have actually spent time on the advisory side can often speak to that very deeply, that they see these behavioral foibles over and over again with their clients. And I know in conversations with you, that's been a very important catalyst for ultimately shaping Aptus. 我经常发现，行为金融学的教训在亲眼目睹时尤为深刻。许多我交谈过的投资组合经理，他们实际上在咨询方面有过经验，往往能深刻地谈论这一点，他们看到客户一次又一次地犯下这些行为上的错误。我知道在与你的对话中，这成为了塑造Aptus的最终重要催化剂。也许你可以花点时间谈谈你在咨询业务方面的经历中看到的一些事情，以及你所见证的行为错误。

Customer
This is a big subject for us, obviously. We're focused a lot on how can you help steer behavior to where you're truly going to enhance outcomes because the biggest detriment we really feel is behavior. And everybody, it's kind of like one of the hot words right now, behavior, whatever. And everybody talks about it, talk about the behavior gap and things like that. But it's a real problem. It's a problem that we're aware of, but I still don't think enough is done to really address it and to minimize it. And you're exactly right. I came into the world, the real world, extremely green. I had a decent amount of education behind me, but I'm coming into the world kind of at the tail end of the crisis where you can take your picture perfect portfolio and basically rip it up because emotion ruled like what I think it always does. And the best laid plans were getting ripped to shreds because the world was coming to an end or that's on the retail client side. And. The advisor. And so that was the light bulb for us. And the foundation of Aptos was really, hey, this is an issue here. Why is this so powerful? Why is this so detrimental? Is there a way that what can be done to help minimize this? And that's, you know, you can walk through example one after the other of just seeing what makes sense on paper, not actually happening because it doesn't feel right.

这是一个对我们来说非常重要的话题，显然如此。我们非常关注如何引导行为，以真正提升结果，因为我们认为最大的障碍其实是行为。每个人都在谈论这个，行为，行为差距等等。但这是一个真正的问题。我们知道这个问题，但我认为我们还没有采取足够的措施来真正解决它并最小化它。你说得对。我进入现实世界时，非常稚嫩。我接受过相当多的教育，但我进入这个世界时，正值危机的尾声，那时你可以拥有一个完美的投资组合，但基本上会被情绪所摧毁，就像我认为它总是会做的那样。最好的计划也被撕得粉碎，因为世界似乎要结束了，这是在零售客户方面。而顾问也是如此。这对我们来说是一个启示。Aptos的基石就是，这是一个问题。为什么这个问题如此强大？为什么它如此有害？有什么办法可以解决这个问题，以帮助最小化它？你知道，你可以一个接一个地举例说明，看到纸面上合理的方案，实际上并没有发生，因为感觉不对。

Interviewer

And we'll get into that a bit later, but were there any lessons you took away from working at the advisor level and the client level? Any, I don't want to say tricks of the trade necessarily, but anything that you learned that was particularly useful and efficient at controlling and helping guide client misbehavior?

今天你试图在资产管理层面控制许多行为问题。我们稍后会深入探讨这一点，但在你从顾问和客户层面工作中，有没有学到什么经验教训？我不一定说这是行业内的技巧，但你学到了什么特别有用且高效的方法来控制和引导客户的错误行为？

Customer
Yes, and this will tie into more discussion, I'm sure, but from the advisor's seat, I think it's extremely critical to have conviction in process. That requires either somebody that can help with that conviction or time and energy to build that conviction. So that conviction is what helps you communicate to the end user and what helps you minimize some of the pushback that is inevitable when markets get volatile. So the first thing that I think now, education and all that type of stuff, but you have to have conviction with the person that is kind of the point man. That is how you start to chip away at the behavior gap.

是的，我相信这将会引发更多讨论，但从顾问的角度来看，我认为对流程的坚定信念极其关键。这需要有人帮助建立这种信念，或者投入时间和精力来培养这种信念。这种信念有助于你向最终用户传达信息，并在市场波动不可避免时减少一些阻力。所以，我认为现在首先要做的，是教育和培养这种信念，但你必须对那个关键人物有坚定的信念。这就是你开始缩小行为差距的方式。

Interviewer
You spent about three years on the advisory front, but did ultimately transition to a more research driven role. Can you pick up the story there, pick up the thread about what you were doing? I believe it was a deep value research role, which again, not quite where you're at today, but maybe you can tell us a little bit about that role, the sorts of research you were doing and lessons learned.

你在咨询前线大约花了三年时间，但最终还是转向了更偏研究驱动的角色。你能继续讲述那个故事吗，继续讲述你在那个阶段的工作内容？我相信那是一个深度价值研究的角色，虽然这与你现在的职位不完全相同，但或许你可以跟我们分享一下那个角色的一些细节，你当时进行的那些研究，以及从中获得的经验教训。

Customer
I've really been fortunate from some of the experiences that I've had that have been great at giving me an idea of what's out there and where I think we could improve on certain things. So I got out of the wire house community just because it's not for me. And some of the things that you have to do on top of what you really want to do, I wasn't a huge fan of. But I took a job to really get into the back office because I wanted to be in the spreadsheets. I wanted to be looking at individual equities. I wanted to be figuring things out. And so I worked with two charter holders that have a really sound process when it comes to valuation, both on the macro front. So I was running a lot of economic models, looking at high level stuff, whether when it comes to the economy and the world economy. And that was a world that I really hadn't touched before. That was really helpful. Got to learn how to do cool things with different databases and things like that. But I was also doing deep dives on individual. So they'd say, hey, we're interested in this space. Here's 20 names. Filter it down to five and we'll take it from there. So that type of work with some of the models that they had built, seeing kind of how they saw the world and how they approached it, opened so many ideas and questions that I was able to run down and kind of find the answer myself for.

我真的很幸运，从一些经历中获得了宝贵的见解，这些经历让我对现有的情况有了清晰的认识，并且让我意识到我们在某些方面可以有所改进。所以我离开了经纪商社区，因为那不适合我。有些事情你不得不做，而这些事情并不是你真正想做的，我对此并不热衷。但我选择了一份工作，真正深入到后台，因为我想要接触电子表格，想要研究个股，想要解决问题。于是，我与两位特许持有人合作，他们在估值方面有着非常扎实的流程，无论是宏观层面还是微观层面。所以我运行了许多经济模型，研究了一些高层次的内容，无论是关于经济还是世界经济。这是一个我以前从未触及过的领域，这对我非常有帮助。我学会了如何利用不同的数据库做一些很酷的事情。但我也深入研究了个别公司。他们会说，“我们对这个领域感兴趣，这里有20家公司，筛选出5家，然后我们再继续。”通过这种工作方式，结合他们构建的模型，我看到了他们如何看待世界以及如何处理问题，这激发了许多想法和问题，我能够深入探究并自己找到答案。

Customer
Here's what I took from it all, really, the biggest clash. Do I think fundamentals matter? Yes, I do. Do I think there's factors that are really important to have exposure to? For sure. And my answer is no, they don't. They do not. The system is what matters. And yes, we could get into some arguments on this for sure. But if you're going to get exposure to the value anomaly, if you're going to get exposure to momentum, if you're going to get exposure to you name it, it's not value, it's not momentum. Yes, you should be tilting towards those things because of the evidence that supports it. But the system which you put in place to do it is what it trumps everything. 我从这一切中真正领悟到的是，最大的冲突在于：我认为基本面重要吗？是的，我认为重要。我认为有一些因素确实非常重要，值得我们去关注吗？当然。价值、动量、质量，所有这些因素都很重要。但与之相对的观点是，这些因素有多重要，或者它们是否比现有的系统更重要？我的答案是否定的，它们并不比系统更重要。系统才是关键。是的，我们完全可以就此展开争论。但如果你打算利用价值异常，如果你打算利用动量，或者你打算利用其他任何因素，那么，重要的不是价值，也不是动量。是的，你应该倾向于那些有证据支持的因素。但你所建立的系统才是决定一切的关键。我可以让我的六岁女儿选股票。如果她有一个系统，能够让她持续地赢多输少，她就能利用市场创造财富。而这正是推动一切的核心。

Interviewer

Customer
So what do we know about the market that's really, you can't dispute it? What are the few simple, simple truths about the market that we can boil down to that's really just plain Jane, here's the facts? Well, how do you build a system that touches different components of the market that's always going to adhere to those simple truths? And those simple truths are, if you just own the market in general, I would argue you're going to create wealth. If you just go by the SPY, you're going to create wealth. Well, if you look at the SPY going back to its launch date or whatever, like, well, what has generated those gains? So everything that we do, whether it's tilting to different factors or anything, the system is built upon, can we win bigger than we lose and still deliver the factor exposure that we're trying to deliver? And some of the background that ties into that is when you're building short-term systematic strategies, like nothing else matters other than the size of your wins to the size of your losses. If you're going to be 40 to 60 percent right, well, if you do the math, if your ratio is one for one, I'm going to win one, I'm going to lose one in terms of size of P&L, you're really not moving the needle at all. 那么，关于市场，有哪些事实是无可争议的呢？有哪些简单、简单的事实是我们能够提炼出来的，这些事实就是市场的本质？那么，你如何构建一个触及市场不同组成部分的系统，这个系统总是会遵循这些简单的事实呢？这些简单的事实就是，如果你只是持有市场总体，我会说你将会创造财富。如果你只是跟随SPY（标普500指数ETF），你也会创造财富。那么，如果你回顾SPY自推出以来的表现，是什么创造了这些收益呢？这些收益来自于极少数股票，它们以巨大的方式推动了市场的变化。有很多公司已经倒闭，有很多公司失去了市值，有很多公司做了所有不利于结果的事情。但市场仍然在变动，因为你会有几只股票的胜利远远超过其他所有股票。因此，我们做的所有事情，无论是倾向于不同的因子还是其他什么，系统的基础都是，我们能否赢得比输得更多，同时还能提供我们试图提供的因子暴露？这其中的一些背景是，当你构建短期系统性策略时，除了你的胜利与损失的大小之外，其他什么都不重要。如果你有40%到60%的正确率，那么如果你做一下数学计算，如果你的胜负比是一比一，我在盈亏规模上赢一输一，你实际上并没有推动市场的变化。但如果你是四比一，即使你的命中率只有30%，你仍然在推动市场的变化。这实际上就是我们所说的赢得比输得更多的基础。

Customer
Diversification is the most overused word in the financial world. So really where this idea, one thing, especially in the constraints of like a long only allocator, true diversification is nearly impossible. I mean, if you said, hey, I'm going to put together, we're going to own eight asset classes and they're going to have zero correlation. We're going to be long only in all eight asset classes. So where kind of my ideas around diversification started to flesh out was in the future space. Well, you can trade 40 markets in the future space, 40 different contracts. 分散化是金融界最被滥用的词汇之一。实际上，在某些情况下，尤其是在仅限于做多分配者的约束下，真正的分散化几乎是不可能的。我的意思是，如果你说：“嘿，我们将组合起来，拥有八个资产类别，并且它们之间的相关性为零。我们将在所有八个资产类别中仅做多。让我们开始行动吧。”听起来在纸面上很棒，你会显著降低风险和回撤等。但在仅做多的背景下，这种情况并不存在。因此，我对分散化的想法开始具体化的地方是在期货领域。嗯，你可以在期货领域交易40个市场，40个不同的合约。你很快就会意识到，你可能同时进行八笔交易。你实际上只有一笔交易，即利率如何影响货币，股票如何影响。它们都是相互关联的。因此，这回到了一个观点。好吧，真正的分散化并不一定意味着不同的资产类别。它确实意味着系统和该系统提供的回报风险特征是重要的。

Customer

是的，我们将持有50只股票。这些股票基本上来自于市值最大的前1000家美国上市股票。因此，我们关注的是中大型市值的股票。我们通过三个指标来构建所谓的“价值综合评分”。我们关注的是一种投资资本回报率，基本上是在评估账面上用于产生现金流量的资产是什么，以及这些资产的效率如何。我们将这些资产的效率与整个市场进行比较。我们关注的另一个指标是企业价值现金流比率。我们认为这有助于偏向价值投资，同时结合初始筛选的价值和质量因素，这非常有意义。第三个我们关注的指标是市盈率相对于自身历史水平的比较。我们之前没有见过类似的指标，这使得我们不一定偏向于纯粹的价值投资，而是关注市盈率相对于其自身历史水平的变化。举个例子，比如苹果公司，假设其当前的市盈率为20。我们会回顾过去五年的数据，找出苹果在过去五年中最低的市盈率水平。如果当前的市盈率越接近过去五年的最低水平，那么它的排名就会越高。这意味着，如果我们考虑到这一点，它并不会让我们完全排除在外。因此，我们每个季度都会根据这些指标进行调整和再平衡，但同时也会考虑股票的表现。这一点我们之前也提到过，是一个很大的区别。

Customer
So the idea is not only a complimentary basket, but also risk management. So that's where the tail hedging came into play. And so what we do is exactly what you said. We buy puts on the market that from the high level view, people probably think we're just taking 50 bips and throwing it out the window. But in that premium, the price you pay for those puts, there's five ingredients. Obviously, one of the big ones is volatility. And so the level of volatility is going to impact the premium. When the level of volatility is low, your potential protection is going to be much greater than what it would be if volatility was high because you're picking up more. You're getting more bang for your buck. So the very simplified way of thinking about a true tail hedge is you buy something for really cheap that looks like it will never do anything positive for you. And as soon as volatility wakes up, the premium. And that could explode. That's what a true tail hedge is.

所以，这个想法不仅仅是构建一个补充性的投资组合，还涉及到风险管理。这就是尾部对冲策略的用武之地。我们做的正是你所说的：我们在市场上购买看跌期权。从宏观角度来看，人们可能会认为我们只是在浪费50个基点的资金。但在这些期权的溢价中，价格包含了五个要素。显然，其中一个重要的因素是波动性。波动性的水平会影响溢价。当波动性较低时，你获得的潜在保护将远大于波动性较高时的保护，因为你能够以更低的成本获得更多的保护。所以，一个非常简化的理解尾部对冲的方式是，你以非常低的价格购买一些看似永远不会对你产生积极影响的东西。而一旦波动性上升，溢价可能会迅速增加。这就是真正的尾部对冲策略。

Interviewer
The intuition there being that it's easier for the market to drop 50% when volatility is at 20% than it is when volatility is at 5%.

直觉上，当波动率为20%时，市场下跌50%的可能性比波动率为5%时要大。

Customer
Yes, exactly. So when you buy, all options have a time to expiration. So if you buy an option, I'm making these numbers up, that the premium's a dollar and it expires next year, 12 months from now. Well, if nothing happens to the underlying security that the option is on and you move out in time three months, absolutely nothing has happened. Well, the premium, you're still going to lose money in that premium because there's going to be some time decay because there's less time. So the option is less valuable. So when you're looking at puts that we're looking at far out of the money, the market knows if you look at, this is another interesting topic, but if you look at the distribution of returns in the market, there's a big fat left tail. So everybody's probably remember stats 101, the normal bell curve. Well, the market's returns are not normally distributed. There's a huge left tail, meaning the market is aware that a left tail event, a big negative event, is going to be a big fat left tail. So if you look at the distribution of returns in the market, you're going to see that the left tail event is more likely than a right tail event. So for that reason, where we're buying in the time to expiration and out of the money, you get a little bit of, I guess, relief from that time decay because you're going to get a, the volatility is going to naturally creep up as you get closer and closer to expiration. And that helps us with, hey, if the market just rips straight up, we want to be sure that we're not forfeiting a lot of the upside. And really what we want the tail hedge to do is to be a significant part of the market. So if we're going to get a little bit of relief from that time decay, we want to get a significant offset to a significant drop in price. So if the market were to drop 20% over the next 30 to 60 days, we want our tail hedge to maybe not offset a star for dollar, but really kick in to minimize drawdown. And so we're going to have to wait and see what happens. And so we're going to have to wait and see what happens. And so we're going to have to wait and see what happens. 是的，确实如此。所以当你购买期权时，所有的期权都有一个到期时间。假设你购买了一个期权，我这里随便举个例子，期权的溢价是1美元，到期时间是明年，也就是12个月后。如果期权所基于的标的证券在这期间没有任何变化，而时间已经过去了三个月，确实什么都没有发生。然而，你仍然会在这份期权上亏损，因为随着时间的推移，期权的时间价值会衰减，因为剩下的时间变少了。因此，期权的价值会降低。所以当你在考虑那些深度虚值的看跌期权时，市场知道——这是一个有趣的话题——但如果你观察市场回报的分布，你会发现有一个很大的左尾。大家可能还记得统计学101中的正态分布曲线。然而，市场的回报并不是正态分布的。有一个巨大的左尾，这意味着市场意识到左尾事件，即一个大的负面事件，将会是一个巨大的左尾。因此，如果你观察市场回报的分布，你会发现左尾事件比右尾事件更有可能发生。因此，正因为如此，当我们购买那些到期时间较长且深度虚值的期权时，你会从时间衰减中得到一些缓解，因为随着你越来越接近到期日，波动性自然会上升。这有助于我们，比如，如果市场直接上涨，我们希望确保我们不会放弃太多的上涨空间。我们真正希望尾部对冲能够成为市场的重要部分。因此，如果我们能从时间衰减中得到一些缓解，我们希望得到一个显著的补偿，以应对价格的大幅下跌。所以如果市场在未来30到60天内下跌20%，我们希望我们的尾部对冲能够不仅仅是抵消一美元对一美元的损失，而是真正发挥作用以最小化回撤。在二月初的那一天，市场下跌了4.2%，我们看到了整个市场的波动率全面重置。因此，我们保守地预计在我们的模型中，如果你处于经济衰退时期，你将在接下来的30到50、60天内下跌20%。我们预计波动率会达到什么水平，以及我们的对冲会给我们带来多少补偿？在二月初的短短两个小时内，波动率从当时的水平飙升到我们预计在30多天窗口内会达到的水平。因此，我们的防御策略完全发挥了作用。你看到账户中的这50个基点不再只是50个基点了。所以我们必须等待，看看会发生什么。实际上，我们在那天获得了显著的利润。
